awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) System for Profiling Open Channels
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant will support acquisition of a modular Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) instrument system that will enable fundamental research on stream, river, lake, canals and culverts in North Dakota and the upper Midwest.  ADCP instruments are both boat and static platform deployable and can collect data autonomously.  ADCP allows for spatially and contemporaneously resolved quantification of water velocities profiles and such measurements are necessary across watersheds to better forecast flooding events.  As such the instrument will support research that is poised to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare in that improved flood forecasting can reduces loss of human life, can be used to help mitigate property damage and most efficiently target first responder efforts, and by study of these systems, better civil engineering approaches can be taken to lessen the severity of future flooding events.  The instrument system would support a multi-disciplinary research group of faculty and students from various engineering, science, natural resources, geoscience departments and programs at the University of North Dakota (UND), Valley City State University (VCSU), and Turtle Mountain Community College (TMCC), a tribal college, to conduct water resources related research.  Much of the research is societally relevant and will help to improve flood forecasting and inform water resources management decisions.  The investigators plan to engage K-12 students in experiential leaning of field analytical techniques as applied to research problems in watershed hydrology.

The ADCP that will be purchased using funds from the award will support fundamental research on: the hydrodynamics of open channel flows in snow-melt triggered flooding on North Dakota rivers and streams; studies of the impacts of prairie restoration on stream and river hydrographs; and studies of nutrient, solute and sediment transport dynamics in large rivers and higher order streams, lakes, canals and culverts in North Dakota and the upper Midwest.  ADCP allows for spatially and contemporaneously resolved quantification of complex flow fields where laminar flow and turbulence interact on short timescales.  ADCP relies on the Doppler effect of sound waves scattered back from particles within the water column to allow for flow field and depth profiling of the water bodies with cm-scale resolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funding for this project was used in 2019 for the acquisition of an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP) system that supports measurements of flow parameters in open channels via an autonomous surface vehicle (ASV). The system has allowed a multi-disciplinary research group related to water resources to be formed from four departments within the University of North Dakota. Training for using the ADCP system mounted on an ASV was extended to all the participating programs at the University of North Dakota (UND), Valley City State University (VCSU), and Turtle Mountain Community College (TMCC), a tribal college. Despite several delays in equipment delivery and hands-on training, which were largely attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, many research activities on stream measurements were performed in 2021.

The major research equipment acquisition, training, and successful deployments have led to advances in several disciplines. Dr. Yeo Howe Lim of Civil Engineering at UND worked with graduate students on flow dynamics in river channels around bridges using the ADCP-ASV, He proposed to the North Dakota Department of Transportation (NDDOT) on the potential use of the ADCP-ASV in bridge site investigations. An NDDOT research grant ($79,996) was awarded in 2021 with the objectives of investigating potential scour formations at two bridge sites along the Red River of the North using the ADCP-ASV system and model potential scour formation under extreme flooding conditions. A scour formation can lead to a bridge failure. Early detection of underwater scour formation and providing appropriate countermeasures would alleviate hazardous conditions to the public. The project is in progress and will end in 2023.

Dr. Taufique Mahmood in Geological Engineering of UND has started a research project, in collaboration with Dr. Lim and graduate students, to study the thermal factor of shallow lakes considering dynamics mixing between lakes making use of the ADCP-ASV system. The study is supported by a seed grant ($25,000) awarded by the College of Engineering & Mines (Lim and Mahmood, 2021).

Dr. Gregory Vanderburg of Geography and Dr. Jeff VanRoy of Earth System Science and Policy at UND, together with Dr. Lim and Dr. Mahmood, have been instrumental in developing a collaborative group and taking advantage of the availability of the ADCP-ASV system. Several major research proposals were submitted by the group to NASA and NSF.

UND is a growing public university in North Dakota. The addition of major research instrumentation such as this ADCP-ASV system has enhanced the research capacity, allowing students to explore new frontiers in science and engineering. In particular, the ADCP-ASV is elevating the understanding of flow dynamics in open channel flows in rivers and streams in North Dakota and the Upper Midwest.
